Expectation1: Respect the mentor's time and availability.
Situation1: The mentor has set aside open office hours throughout the week.
Expectation2: Meet sales targets set by management
Situation2: With only an hour left in the shift, they are still a few sales short of the weekly target.
Story:
I stared at the clock, my headset pressing into my ear, the hum of the call center buzzing around me. Only an hour left in my shift, and I was still three sales short of my weekly target. My manager’s words echoed in my mind: “We need you to hit your numbers, or we’ll have to talk about your future here.” I scrolled through my call list, heart pounding, knowing every minute counted.

Then, a calendar notification popped up on my screen: “Mentor Office Hours—Drop in anytime this week.” My mentor had been clear—these hours were for me, a chance to ask questions and get guidance, but only if I respected her time and didn’t wait until the last minute. I’d promised myself I’d go today, but now, with the sales target looming, I hesitated. If I left my desk, I’d lose precious calling time. If I stayed, I’d miss the chance to connect with my mentor, who’d set aside this time just for me.

My fingers hovered over the mouse, torn between dialing the next number and logging off to meet my mentor, feeling the weight of both expectations pressing in from either side.
